urlLink WHO WE ARE : We meet at Kherryâs house or ( alfresco ) at Skinnerâs Butte Park every other Thursday evening (in Eugene, Oregon) and have since late 2003. Anyone can join (and once a member, always a member). WHAT WE DO : We analyze short fiction, poetry, books, and recent movies: their strengths and weaknesses, what we like and donât like about them. We also bring in our own writing to be commented on by members, and we experiment with writing exercises and assignments. OUR PHILOSOPHY : All of us in America haved learned to write via ânegative feedbackâ (akin to the piano student learning to play whileher teacher stands above her, ruler-in-hand). Hence, most of us have trouble expressing ourselves creatively on page. Itâs no wonder! And itâs terribly hard to get honest yet supportive feedback. Our approach is to modify these negative approaches from the past. We do this by discussing what we LIKE about a piece first; from there (after credibility has been set, and it takes careful work, sometimes, but thereâs always something good about a writing sample), we talk about what we didnât like or didnât understand. Weâre supportive of each otherâs growth and believe our writing can be further perfected. CURRENT MEMBERS ARE : urlLink Kherry -- Jade -- urlLink Nathan -- urlLink Amy -- Sherry -- Terri. urlLink People who enjoy the piano in general and my playing in particular have asked over the years that I explain my approach to playing. One sweet woman and mother of a teen student asked, "What should I do so that 'Johnny' might play like you?" I was taken back by the question and said something like: "Johnny will have a unique sound, don't worry -- because he's a unique person, and musician, and we all have a unique sound." Weeks went by after this incident, and I thought about her compliment more deeply. I realized what I said to her wasn't a real response to her question. She was noticing something very true about piano playing. In fact, many pianists sound a lot alike. And she somehow knew in this world of specialization, Johnny's only hope was to develop his own sound. She's delved into a more important question; the words she'd used didn't quite do her imagination justice. She was attempting, I now see, to ask something like, "How can I help Johnny veer away from run-of-the-mill, 'standard' piano playing and find more of a unique, creative, 'expressive' sound, a sound I associate, at least at times, with you?" If I could have answered her again, this is what I would say. First, I'd ask her a few questions, a superb way of filtering through what might become a web of misunderstandings as our talk progressed. I'd ask her what musicians she likes and what period of piano music, in particular. I'd ask her if she hoped Johnny might make a living from music, either as a nightly piano grinder, or even, if he's lucky, as a recording artist. I'd then ask her to sit and close her eyes. Using quasi-regressional techniques, I'd ask her about her first memories regarding music. What was the first song she remembered? How did it move her? When did she understand what "music" was (as opposed to noise), and how did that affect her? Answering the same for her, I would mention a 78 LP-folk recording of 'Puff the Magic Dragon' as the first moment I realized I was listening to a "song": what I'd come to understand was a string of notes composed (I would have used "made up" then) solely for my enjoyment and that of others. I was about five at the time. I realized then, as I listened about Puff and how he lived by the Sea, that someone had "pretended" Puff to entertain me and had made up a melody to tell the story. They had made up the notes or "tones" that comprised his story, and these were meant to sound pleasing, to be memorable. I'd realized I was listening to a "song." I knew, too, that its greatest power was that it made me feel , and not just feel any old way: to feel sad for Puff; to feel his loneliness; to feel especially for Puff having to go away. I understood the song's themes: friendship, saying goodbye, and growing up (though at five, only as a five-year-old does). More importantly, though, I stepped back (the only way I can describe it) and saw that a song (and music in general) are very special ways to be told something, told a story, or be made to feel. I, and I remember actually thinking this, knew that a song was no doubt the MOST POWERFUL way a person can convey feelings to another. I was amazed. I looked at the LP's dust jacked and circular insert, reading the information it offered. It was like receiving a present from God. Years past. Like many middle-class kids, I began taking music lessons. I started with the clarinet, age nine. I was not very good. I didn't care much for the its sound, and worse, blowing into it made my cheeks sore. I rarely practiced. I'd played around with an old hammond organ we had in our house through my childhood, so when we acquired a new piano, I decided to try lessons. I was eleven or twelve. To be continued . . . .

urlLink By Kherry McKay California Governor urlLink Arnold Schwarzenegger calls his state legislature â urlLink Girlie Men â for their stall on passing the urlLink $103-billion budget . He says politicians, mostly Democrats, are âpart of a bureaucracy thatâs out of shape, out of date, out of touch, and thatâs definitely out of control in Sacramentoâ (the stateâs capital). It seems Schwarzenegger put his hand purposefully in a feminist beehive. The denunciation of his rhetoric came from all quarters, as nonplused feminists cried fervid complaints. urlLink Senator Sheila Kuehl (D-Santa Monica), chairwoman of the state urlLink Natural Resources and Wildlife Committee and member of the â urlLink Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Caucus â is outraged. urlLink âItâs really painful,â she notes, â. . . to hear the governor resort to such blatant urlLink homophobia . Itâs an old-fashioned way of talking about gay men, to indicate theyâre not . . . strong. So, that part is really painful. And I have to say, itâs really surprising. He canât get his way, so he resorts to name-calling.â urlLink Eleanor Smeal of the urlLink Feminist Majority (a national womenâs rights organization), states, â. . . To denigrate half the human race is pretty sick. But thatâs what [Schwarzenegger] is doing. Heâs trying to denigrate the males by denigrating females.â Assemblywoman urlLink Sarah Reyes (D-Fresno) thinks Schwarzenegger âshould apologize and think twice before he speaks; and I would hope that his wife, urlLink Maria , would remind him of that.â (This makes me urlLink smile, because Reyes hides behind the urlLink social progressivism of urlLink feminism while, at the same time, admonishing the Governor through his wife?) I wonât, though, speak on feminism, urlLink sexism , homophobia, or whether or not a Hollywood action hero should be in office. These topics are interesting, but Iâm not in the mood to say much about them. Suffice it to say, Iâve faced my own homophobia, retain feminist friends (and a few enemies, like us all), think urlLink gender stereotyping is wrong, etc. And I also know good rhetorical tactics when I see them. urlLink What I really want to proclaim is how brilliant the use of the term â urlLink Girlie Men â was on Arnoldâs part. (And, letâs face it, the Terminator planned it -- using it twice. His wife, Maria Shriver, no doubt knew he intended to use the phrase. It remains to be seen whether or not Maria will rebuff her buff hubby for his etymological taste.) The term âGirlie Man,â for those young enough to know (or old enough to remember), came to the public ear from the hilarious urlLink Saturday Night Live âHans and Franzâ skits performed by urlLink Dana Carvey and urlLink Kevin Nealon to spoof bodybuilders, urlLink infomercials , and people as big as Schwarzenegger. Carvey and Nealon pretended to motivate their viewers, called each slacker âGirlie Menâ as well as âsissies,â used fake Romanian accents and shouted, âWe want to -- PUMP - YOU - UP!!â urlLink The genius of Schwarzenegger utilizing âGirlie Menâ as a back-slap to vex the slow-poke CA senate is: on the one hand, everyone knows heâs calling them urlLink WIMPY (using a vernacular jest) yet on the other, even if the phrase has a slight (or not-so-slight) homophobic sense , people remember Schwarzenegger enduring the same abuse. During the time of the sketches, the Cyberdyne Star didnât get uptight or stave off Carvey or Nealon. He went on Saturday Night Live and joined in the fun, making light of the general myopism of urlLink bodybuilding and the low-brow side of infomercials, relishing in his own self-deprecation. urlLink What a sly choice of his to use âGirlie Menâ -- for it was sure to get headlines, urlLink hullaballoo , make his point, and remind people of his Hollywood clout, all in one swoop! Feminists can fume and clamor, but the public at large generally accepts the epigram as an alternative to âwimpinessâ for the precise reason that itâs descriptive, funny, and chic. Iâll venture to say, weâll be hearing a ping-pong pejorative like âGirliemen Women â soon enough, so nobody should feel left out. (I doubt the pundits have the courage to coin something like â Boy Dame ,â however.) In the twenty-first century, the ability to chuckle at yourself -- and your interests -- far outshines your dogedness at political correctness. I really would have loved to have been in the meeting in which Schwarzenegger asked for opinions on his phraseology! No offense, Ms. Kuehl, but the strategists in the room decided âGirlie Menâ didnât refer to homosexuals, but instead, stood as a fresh way to heighten gubernatorial visibility and wield Arnold power. It was their âlead-sausageâ (and stop the hee-heeâs ). Theyâll prove right in the end.

An old spiritual question -- and a question Iâve been personally asking God the entire year (by God , I donât mean the deity of a specific religion, but the God urlLink of My Life; I call him âFatherâ) -- goes: âHow much of our energy and action, God,should come from us (i.e., from our wills) and how much from You ?â There are helpful and not-so-helpful theories on this. A Christian phrase says, â urlLink Let go and let God ;â another, in Spanish, hints similarly, âVia con Dios,â or â Go with God .â In the urlLink idiosyncratic U.S., the apt but certainly off-kilter maxim is: â urlLink God helps those who help themselves .â This last attempts -- as it fails -- to crack a conundrum inside âIt all must be of Godâ -- to wit, if itâs ALL God, why do we have to get up in the morning? God helps those who help themselves says we have responsibilities. Doesnât God involve himself only with souls that are attempting to fully LIVE a life and not hiding under a rock? (Generally; but urlLink consider Jonah . God, at times, gets quite involved with some of his hiding sheep.) But why canât it be ALL him? I admire the Chinese mystical idea in this context offered by urlLink Lao Tsu : âI do nothing and nothing is left undone.â It subtly hints at Spiritâs efficacy and sums up the Chinese way of thinking about heaven. urlLink Lao Tsu would interpret it: â urlLink You know when youâre getting Heavenâs aidwhen things actually get done â and yet you have no pride or ownership of result .â Easy to say; very, very hard to do. . . . For me, the last three months have felt like a four-credit intensive course in learning how to do nothing (and trusting the right things will get done, anyway). Iâve come to see I often go off pursuing the next thing, or job, or project, or woman, or âLife Experienceâ without waiting for God to initiate, and things soon groan to a rusty stop. Iâm constantly picking up pieces and trying to undo urlLink problems caused by my rushing and forcing things instead of waiting for (and going with) God. Last month was especially peaceful because I went to Him each day and said, â urlLink Father, I trust you. Bring me what you would; put the right thing into my heart. â It seemed to work. Iâve been looking for a job, and Iâve done so calmly and without investment in getting anything particular. Iâve not allowed myself to charm or manipulate (even with subtle forms of charm, the kind we often use) to get opportunities. Now, so far I havenât found work. But importantly, I havenât got the wrong job, either, which is something that hasnât always been the case. For now, Iâm on hold , stuck in urlLink geosynchronous orbit until God directs me to act. Things like a new mattress and box spring have come which I didnât even know I needed until I came to understand Iâd been suffering from urlLink sleep deprivation for a year. I have three friends coming at the end of the month to visit, and Iâve worried Iâll be poor as Jobâs turkey or will have just begun employment when they come and wonât have much time. (Does the reader see the pointlessness of my concern?) urlLink A small plug for urlLink Mysticism and Iâll close: All of this assumes a certain urlLink anthropomorphic , person-like God or Spirit that truly cares . The âborn-againâsâ words about having a personal relationship with God are for the most part right, even if their ideas are confused with with urlLink legalism , shame, and anger. Trusting that the Father truly cares is key: that he watches over us, and above wanting to give acclaim or riches, desires for us to learn to trust. âHow much should action come from us?â Our most important act is TRUST. Our contribution is admitting we need God and little else.Blessingscome (more often than we know), but we have to overcome fear and our misunderstandings, like thinking God âfailed us,â and reach upward -- as a child would -- letting Spirit do , letting heaven fill out our calendars, give us friends, jobs, money, or success as seen fit. The Father knows what we need. âAll things shall be added if we urlLink seek the Kingdom first ,â said his beloved. Itâs lifeâs purpose, the raison dâetre of âExperiment Earthâ-- to learn this. When weâve mastered it, we graduate, floating on to a new curriculum. Note on Post Title: Chaucer in Troilus and Criseyde said: âMaketh virtue of necessite!â The phrase suggests, if things get beyond control, thereâs no sense in getting frustrated -- instead, relax and use a bad situation productively. (Courtesy of the urlLink Morris Dictionary of Word and Phrase Origins, 2nd Ed . ).
